Emerging Markets equities could still surprise on the upside. There are a number of supportive factors over the medium term, including China's V-shaped recovery. The relative GDP growth gap of EM to DM will be 3.3% in 2021 compared to only 1.6% in 2019 and 3.1% this year.
USD has peaked, but is not due for a major downtrend. GBP is most vulnerable over the near term, and upward pressure will persist for CHF and JPY.
We’ve seen record U.S. fixed income supply in 2020, but demand should push spreads tighter in the 2H 2020.
S&P 500 still has 10% upside from current levels by early 2021, while technicals remain supportive with hedge fund and CTA positioning at only the ~25th to 30th percentile.
Markets remain supported by central bank actions and fiscal support.

Global growth is experiencing a consumer-led midyear bounce after the plunging by 16% in 1H, but the resurgence in the virus points to an incomplete recovery and a loss of output, profits and employment that won’t be fully recouped in 2020 and 2021.

So what The health of the Treasuries market is essential for cash management, hedging, and other critical operations. By providing more repo operations, the Fed helps improve liquidity in the treasuries market. More financing for dealers will allow them to trade more.

How does it work The Treasury market depends on dealers for liquidity in the primary and secondary markets. Recent market volatility left dealers holding record amounts of treasuries causing market liquidity to fall.
Why did they do it To help stabilize government securities markets by providing much-needed liquidity to the primary intermediaries.

Yesterday the Fed announced an additional $500B in overnight repo financing and additional purchases of Treasuries directly from large securities dealers. J.P. Morgan’s head of U.S. Interest Rate Strategy, Alex Roever, breaks down what it means.

Historically, a market sell-off of this magnitude implied a 65-75% chance of a recession in the next year. However, in our view, the market has priced in too severe of an adverse scenario; assuming a timely, strong counter-policy response, & a peak of COVID-19 in coming weeks.

The volatility comes against a backdrop of investors moving from equities into the safer haven of bonds. In the last month for instance, we estimate that retail and institutional equity fund flows have seen ~$40B in outflows.

The sharp sell-off is also symptomatic of a fragile market structure that can amplify price both downside and upside—a volatility shock coinciding with a collapse in liquidity and significant forced selling by systematic portfolios (that is now largely complete).
Monday’s sell-off represents a “black swan” event, with the oil price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia turning an already fragile backdrop into a perfect storm for risky assets.
